There's a devillish glee to this rather clever adaptation of Bret Easton Ellis's horrifically caustic novel, and it works a treat. It expertly depicts a hidden psycho in the corporate finance world but also pokes merciless fun at his very madness. It helps enormously that the serial killer Patrick Bateman is played by a buffed-up Christian Bale in peak form. He totally nails the dead eyes of a cold-blooded killer, living in a world where a man so relentlessly evil is barely even noticed.

The world in which ‚ÄúAmerican Psycho‚Äù is set is planned down to the last detail: from the training schedule,the care program to the sex life. Nothing is coincidental. Patrick Bateman attaches great importance to control and controllability. However, he is one thing above all: never really present. He resembles a bitter principle in which no clearly identifiable emotion is reflected, apart from greed and disgust. And so, of course, the figure is also to be understood as a figurative commentary‚Ä¶

Bret Easton Ellis' American Psycho is a tough book to handle with some of the most horrific scenes of torture I have ever read. When it comes to pseudo-horror, there are so many options out there that it becomes impossible to pick one. An adaptation of Bret Easton Ellis‚Äôs book, American Psycho stars Christian Bale as Patrick Bateman, a New York banking exec who hides his psychopathic alter-ego from all his friends and co-workers while spiraling into disturbingly sadistic fantasies. Besides being a horror movie, American Psycho is filled with dark and somewhat uproarious humor. You‚Äôll be both cringing and laughing while watching this one.

80s satire with lots of blood and Christian Bale nudity. It has some of the best dialogue in a movie. It's razor sharp, funny and quite lyrical. Hypnotically brilliant crime thriller, with a star-making performance by the amazing Christian Bale. His multi-layered interpretation of psychotic killer Patrick Bateman leaves you stunned, mesmerized and in awe of his incredible talent. Bateman's a personal hero of mine. And why wouldn't he be? He wears killer threads, he kills homeless people, and he has insane bouts of jealous rage over nothing.

Pitch perfect razor-sharp period satire, darkest black comedy and disturbing horror, American Psycho is a strikingly intelligent, affecting and layered film full of memorable lines and unforgettable scenes. Alongside an enduringly brilliant and chilling character study by Christian Bale as the titular psycho, the film builds an engrossing caricature of the bland hypocrisy and superficiality of upper class greed and vanity that he both revels in and rebels against. Bit of a masterpiece.

American Psycho is a book some thought to be unfilmable, but writer and director Mary Harron brought the vile character of Patrick Bateman to life in movie that is more of a dark comedy than your average horror movie.

This is a valiant effort by director Mary Harron to adapt Brett Easton Ellis' extreme satire to the big screen. It couldn't have been an easy task since the book is a web of dark humor and obscure 80's references (and some not so obscure ones) and lists, and lists, and lists of Elite New York Yuppie Approved products, services, restaurants, etc. Some of the satire is lost in the translation, but Harron and her co-screenwriter can hardly be blamed.‚Ä¶

A twisted tale of greed, obsession, individualism, and appearances, American Psycho could be seen as the fucked-up brother to Clerks. Both deal with the struggle to break out of the monotony and stagnation of one's current existence, and showcases how the struggles of an individual are pushed aside in an effort to conform to the expected norm. Dante deals with this by playing hockey and complaining, but Patrick deals with it by fantasizing about killing a whole bunch of people,‚Ä¶

Another oldie. This was for those who don‚Äôt know is the story focuses on bateman(Christian Bale) a stereotypical yuppie who also happens to be a psycho. I expected it to be disturbing and gory, but after seeing it i don‚Äôt think its either.

What an interesting companion piece this is to The Wolf of Wall Street. American Psycho presents its take on '80's era Wall Street greed in the context of savage satire via horror movie conventions. An exhilarating and dark character piece that pulls the viewer into the mind of a maniac, and his hidden lifestyle. Christian Bale delivers a powerfully disturbing performance that makes us realize the existence of these thoughts in everyone's psyche. The films only real fault in my opinion, is its stereotypical and overused resolution.

Bale's diction is chewing scenery rendered audible, which makes nothing about Harron's intermittently clever film more insufferable than his pop-music philosophizing. The humor is layered - Bateman is clueless but implausibly eloquent (in the sense that he's speaking words people would only write, not in the sense that what he's saying is on point) but no one is listening anyway because he's just the piece of meat he's made himself into, except that he's not because he's also a maniac‚Ä¶

Could've used a more refined dialectic, especially in the last shot where Bale ruminates on whether he's just been fantasizing or whether class structure has become a leviathan of blinding proportions, where a company man can literally get away with murder. The ostensible point being that Bale may be a hero - a man who's pleading with the masses to reconnect, who isn't so desensitized that human lust, desire, etc. are no longer part of the picture, murdering practically to‚Ä¶

A sharp, off-beat, memorizing, and disturbingly hilarious satire on the Wall Street lifestyle in the 1980s. Christian Bale is absolutely brilliant here, perfectly portraying both the psycho and charismatic billionaire side of Patrick Bateman masterfully. He's pretty despicable, but Bale makes him such a compelling and fascinating character to watch that it almost becomes hard not to like him. On top of that, the film's well directed, the cinematography is pretty stunning, the dialogue is extremely witty and memorable, and‚Ä¶

From the perspective of one who has read the book, I have to say that this wasn't too bad of a film adaptation. Because everything from the book cannot be fit, Mary Harron took pieces from it and rearranged the events to tell the story more smoothly since the film does not include everything; I thought this was an interesting decision. Another clever thing she does is having Patrick Bateman's music artist monologues that are spoken to the reader and‚Ä¶

Damn. I was surprised at just how well this film works as a whole despite it hinging almost completely on the absolutely brilliant lead performance from Christian Bale. The script is darkly uproarious, sardonic, and wickedly funny. The direction and cinematography is rather plain, but the other aspects make up for it. At its core, American Psycho is a dark examination Wall Street, the lives of the people within, and the conformity that blankets the lifestyle. And what a killer soundtrack.

To be quite frank, I'm not entirely sure whether or not I liked American Psycho. The soft rock soundtrack is appropriately contrarian, the film houses one fantastic performance, and the satire against the cleanly unclean corporate world is on point. The characters here are shallow and useless, and it's hard to get a grip on most of them, but that's sort of the point; they're caricatures, phantoms, and Patrick Bateman is the most unreal of them all, but more on‚Ä¶

A beautiful and unique film to look at, despite its gruesome subject. That of yuppie businessman Patrick Bateman (Christian Bale) who seems to be so empty inside that needs to go on murdering sprees at night to keep himself alive. All the depictions of the 80s, and the rich/famous lifestyles are spotless, plus the performances are quite good, albeit somewhat caricaturesque. Still, it's a darn good film with interesting twists and an ending to leave you thinking about.

Awesome movie. Patrick Bateman might just be one of my favorite movie characters, and this is definitely Christian Bale's best work. American Psycho is the story of a Wall Street executive who lives the high life by day and descends into a murderous monster at night. Patrick Bateman, played by Christian Bale, must struggle to find a healthy balance between his bloodlust and his career. There are some moments that are disturbingly, darkly funny, and although the film isn't always terrific, it's still an interesting and watchable movie.

Many still consider this to be the best performance of Christian Bale's career. American Psycho is pretty much a feminist take on the cynical and selfish urban professional male of the late 1980's. It's sort of left up in the air as to what is supposed to be real and what is supposed to be fiction. Some consider that to be a weak link in the movie, but I love that it's left open to interpretation.

Enjoyable from the start, American Psycho veered way more toward black comedy than it did into the gratuitous violence I was led to believe it had. The book (from memory) certainly contained a lot more detail in terms of the violent encounters, and the movie does right to lighten most of the detail there and concentrate more on the satirical humour and Bateman's unwinding.

A very strong remark on American, capitalist society in which Christian Bale pulls off one of the greatest acting performances of his illustrious career. His fantastic portrayal of the manic Patrick Bateman keeps the us questioning reality, which is exactly the point. We are reliant on Bateman as he is the narrator and the film is all through his perspective, however when he is unable to follow reality, neither are we. American Psycho is a one of a kind, mind warping experience.

Another one of my many favorites, a highly criticized movie and very controversial book that the film is an adaptation of. A misunderstood piece of work that is postmodern and being set in 1987, a satirical representation of materialism, misogyny, and machismo, poking fun at the working class yuppies. A feminist film that they didn't pick up on as feminist because of the post modernism. A hilarious, yet violent movie that gets better every time I see it. If you see it, you see it. Bret Easton Ellis' novel is a masterwork of satire. The book so relies on the protagonist, Patrick Bateman, and his characterization to set the perfect tone, that turning the book into a film would be a nigh impossibility.‚Ä¶

If you ever take a general psychology class in College, chances are at some point you will talk about Freud's model of the psychic apparatus in his theory of Psychoanalysis. The three parts of the apparatus include the id, ego, and super-ego. The id is the part of your personality structure where your basic unorganized desires come from, the ego tries to find realistic and positive ways to please the id, and the super-ego internalizes cultures rules and social norms.‚Ä¶

The kind of film that definitely benefits from a rewatch. The razor sharp satire of alpha male narcissistic yuppie bullshit is hilariously astute and disturbingly still relevant, the spiraling madness and depravity as twisted as it is funny, and it's great to see Christian Bale cut loose in a completely off-the-wall performance. The ending is still contentious, hence the rewatch comment - I found it frustrating when I first watched it about ten years ago, but watching the film as more of a satirical dark comedy it works, just about.

An impeccable portrait of a disintegrating mind, filtered through a sharp satirical takedown of a supremely materialistic, superficial society. Features ultimate Christian Bale. Just about every single scene in the film is memorable. I don't think I could ever watch it too many times.

Patrick Bateman is an investment banker who goes through the social hoops, and plays all the games with his co-workers. He's engaged to a beautiful woman. And the mundane nature of his day-to-day life leads him to becoming a serial killer at night.

A deeply misogynistic film, American Psycho glamorizes the sexist and objectifying lifestyles and ideologies of its main characters. Such a crime is essentially unforgivable, but the film one-ups this disgusting outlook on women through its inane and unjustified "descent into insanity" narrative, which has absolutely nothing of interest at stake. It seems that the film attempts to link greed to insanity, but it does so with such laziness and lack of insight that the easy target is not even reached‚Ä¶

It's a testament to the electricity of Christian Bale's performance that this movie doesn't become tedious. The satire is thuddingly obvious--those white-collar financial dudes sure are brutal, aren't they?--until the movie's final act, when it morphs into something different and almost poignant (again, still largely thanks to Bale's performance), and the plotting, even in the end, is straightforward and repetitive without always putting that repetition to analytical use. More than most other movies I can think of, American Psycho works‚Ä¶

American Psycho is one of the rare few that attempt to be daring in their approach of conveying the concept of the serial killer. Rather than inserting a profound sense of meaning behind their devilish exploits, it simply pulls the rug off the feet of its audience, proving that all of the carnage is simply what it is, nothing less, nothing more, negating one‚Äôs need to impart interpretation.

This movie, while violent and savagely satirical about the vacuous and egocentric nature of the yuppie, is a cleverly toned-down version of Easton Ellis's rather uncompromising book. It would have been so easy to make a film that turned audiences off in droves, but this is skilfully avoided. Bale's performance, too, is pitch-perfect, and has, quite rightly, gone down as one of his best.

I'm left with the feeling that it generally enjoyed the movie, but I also feel like I missed something - something feel incomplete and I'm unsatisfied. That being said, I appreciated the social commentary and over-the-topness of it all.

The story just didn't engage me as much as it used to, maybe because I've seen Dennis in "It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia" done in more detail since. But this movie definitely is good, it just didn't leave as much as an impact with me.

From the vantage point of 2016, it's remarkable that this was ever seen as anything other than camp. As a satire it's not particularly savage (the target being placed firmly in the past), but as a burlesque on the 80s it's, well, fun. But, also, Mary Harron shows an interest in playing with identity - but also in the performative basis of identity - that comes directly out of Judith Butler and others writing on drag. Bret Easton Ellis‚Äô 1991 book American Psycho offered a rather harrowing look back at the seeming end of yuppie relevance in the late 1980s from the comfortable perspective of a new decade. But Mary Harron‚Äôs turn-of-the-millennium cinematic take proved that the novel did not have the last word on a culture that has lost touch with its humanity through greed and vanity. It stands as a testament to the power of the shadow. In Jungian terms, it‚Äôs that darker side‚Ä¶

Bale is perfect, as is everyone else, because not a single one of them is believable as a human being. "I simply am not there", Bateman says in one scene, and he might as well be speaking for everybody. And there's the point of American Psycho; even if everybody in it is a Patrick Bateman, we'd be just as blind to it as they are to him. It could've attacked its satirical targets more viciously, I think, but I'll take it. It's just like the dish Bateman describes in it: Playful, but mysterious.

Patrick Bateman mentions Donald Trump a few times in this...huge surprise. Thanks to a fabulous screenplay and a sickening yet charismatic performance from Christian Bale, "American Psycho" works. Privilege, male insecurity, and consumerism defined, Bateman strives to live up to the conservative ideal superman. Wealthy, handsome, cultured, sexually virile, a perfect yuppie that Reagan would be proud to know. Most of these conservatives that I've ever met have more chips on their shoulders than a poker table, and Bateman is no exception. But hey, crazy or not, the rich white straight guys could get away with murder, even the sitting President said he could.

The superior movie about the complete decadence of traditional moral values in American society that has 'American' in the title and was released between the years 1999 and 2000. It's cruder, more nihilistic, straightforward, poignant, and still has an abundance of compelling literary flourishes brought by plenty of passages that are noticeably verbatim from Bret Easton Ellis' infamous novel. Bale's performance is a masterstroke of an actor and a character that exude copious amounts of self-consciousness and confidence at the same time. Shame about Harron not becoming an established (film) director by now.

I kind of felt like I had gotten the point of "American Psycho" after the first fifteen minutes -- people who are so absorbed in what it means to "live well," flashing their status symbols about in frantic attempts at self-relevance, that underneath the exterior there is nothing but a dark empty vacuum where a soul should be.

Gwen Turner mentions in her commentary that a few years after this film was made, Gloria Steinem briefly became Christian Bale's stepmother. I'm thinking he probably never "thanked" her for his winding up with this role, but Steinem's attempts to sabotage this project (by convincing Leo Di Caprio not to do it) resulted in Harron getting the reins back. So sometimes bad actions actually have positive consequences.

A film that equals its source material, American Psycho is dripping in satire with a reflection on society when Easton Ellis first wrote the novel and is perhaps even more prevalent today. Harron takes the darkness of the novel, and twists it into something quite humourous at times. The dialogue is fantastic, particularly Bateman's monologues, and this is owed to the direction, script writing, as well as the wonderful performances, most noteworthy of which is obviously the unpredictable Christian Bale‚Ä¶

First things first, Bale is absolutely amazing. ¬†He gives one of his best (if not his best) performances here. ¬†It's hard to imagine anyone else being in the role of Bateman. Leto and Dafoe also giving strong performances too.

Christian Bale's Patrick Bateman is deadpan human darkness personified. His face is often blank and unreadable, and yet you seem to always know what he's thinking, always one step away from exploding. It's a chillingly crafted performance, with little to no likable qualities- Misogyny, homophobia, drug use, Holier-Than-Thou White Collar attitude, not to mention the whole murder thing. He's a despicable character that is made fascinating to watch, like peering into our own darkness should we be given no limitations.‚Ä¶

I read Brett Easton Ellis's novel over a decade ago and it's an extraordinary piece of work. The book is essentially an attack on the vacuousness and shallowness of the yuppiedom that plagued eighties' society and a thinly veiled attack on the shallow and damaging aspects of capitalism in general. The book is written from Patrick Bateman's perspective and has an unreliable narrative voice as the author describes the shallowest aspects of his life in meticulous detail. Surface is everything‚Ä¶

"There is an idea of a Patrick Bateman -- some kind of abstraction -- but there is no real me. Only an entity, something illusory. And though I can hide my cold gaze, and you can shake my hand and feel flesh gripping yours, and maybe you can even sense our lifestyles are probably comparable ... I simply am not there."
Another great tragedy of capitalism.

"American Psycho" stands as a darkly fascinating satire, reminiscent in its critique of upper society of Octave Mirabeau's "Le Journal d'une Femme de Chambre." The film brilliantly exposes the veneer of success and wealth that hides a void of emptiness and, at times, outright evil within. It serves as a scathing commentary on the moral decay lurking beneath the polished surface of the elite.

Adapting Bret Easton Ellis' "American Psycho" to the big screen, Mary Harron offers a blood and moisturizer-soaked drama drenched in darkly comic notes and satirical beats. Literate and needle sharp, Harron's film skewers a banal, capitalism inhaling, masculine type that lives and breathes money, materialism, and, in the case of Christian Bale's Patrick Bateman, murder. Bale ideally embodies that type with a sort of Gordon Gekko-meets-Skeletor tortured whimsy, rolling through Harron's sanitized and polished compositions with a devilish and superficial wink. Violent, smirking, and roiling with commentary, the film is solid on all levels.

Truly one of the funniest movies of all time. Christian Bale's Tom Cruise impression pays off in his portrayal of Patrick Bateman, a substandard yuppie very inept at hiding his homicidal tendencies simply because he can afford to be -- the world was made for people like him to get ahead and move forward with as little disruption in the flow of capital as possible. He might be deranged, but he's still unremarkable at the end of the day. A feminist triumph too, despite what Steinem might have you believe.

Weird that the heightened, satiric version of unfettered capitalism, narcissism, and male aggression is still more sympathetic than Donald Trump. Hey, at least Patrick Bateman confined himself to murdering people in his immediate vicinity.

Gets a little better every time I rewatch it. It works on so many levels. As a dark comedy, a horror film, a satire of 80s yuppie culture, a psychological character study, a deconstruction of toxic masculinity, and more. Christian Bale's performance is beyond iconic, perfectly pulling off a sociopath with no real emotions who just wants to "fit in". No wonder Batemen's gone insane, when your whole life is entirely materialistic, you're surrounded by fake friends, and your entire existence is based around your public image, who wouldn't? A perfect movie in my mind. (Ladies please don't take this as a red flag)

One part savage off-beat satire of capitalism and consumerism, Wolf of Wall Street but serial killer, one part ancestor to Nightcrawler. American Psycho not just places us in the head of a sociopath, but in the head of one actively telling us that he's breaking down, trying to tell others about his collapsing facade but no one is listening. Christian Bale reminded me of Mads Mikkelsen's take on Hannibal here, in how he embodies both the facade and the insanity underneath.

The ambiguity of the interactions between Bateman and Kimball is my favorite part of this film. Kimball in one sentence condescendingly and mockingly pretends to agree with Bateman, making small hints that he knows. Then immediately after Bateman begins flop sweating, Kimball starts sympathizing with him and produces the alibi he so desperately needs. It's such a great directorial choice - did the murder actually occur? Was it all in his head? No one knows for sure, and nobody's theory is necessarily wrong.

A lightning in a bottle moment in the career of Mary Harron, Guinevere Turner and Christian Bale, a satire as hilarious as it is concerning, American Psycho will be poignant forever. Bale‚Äôs iconic performance, Herron‚Äôs deft direction (seriously, she deserves more work based on her direction of this film alone!), a fantastic script (based on the controversial Bret Easton Ellis novel), the stellar supporting cast, unforgettable imagery courtesy of the great Andrzej Sekula, strong costume/production design and art direction to recreate the 80‚Äôs Wall Street scene, and an absolutely bangin‚Äô 80‚Äôs soundtrack all coalesce to make this well worth your time.

A wealthy executive starts to lose control over his crazy side, while trying to fit in with his co-workers. This just felt like an excuse to let Christian Bale show off his acting chops and he definitely came with the heat. We also get some good satire on conformity in the executive world.

This psychological thriller is a timeless classic layers that satirize materialism and consumerism to accompany the horror aspects of the film. The ending leaves much to the interpretation of the audience, but it is in my opinion that everything that Patrick Bateman did was in fact real, and nobody simply cared because the capitalist system has consumed humanity to the point that nobody cares what he did. "American Psycho" offers a compelling exploration of materialism, but falls short of providing a nuanced analysis due to its focus on the extremes of consumerism rather than its underlying causes and implications.
